reviewText: I was at the Toronto Film Festival, and THE STATION AGENT was by far the best film I saw there.  At my screening, we all gave it a standing ovation!  It's so nice to see a movie that feels real--and yet totally interesting.  The performances are great.  Funny, sad.  You love these characters--particularly Peter Dinklage.  He's amazing!  This is a small movie that should be huge.  I highly recommend it!!
Perfect.
Great film. Well acted and well written. Peter Dinklage is my favorite actor, and his performance in this film is not to be missed.

Finbar McBride is a little person who works repairing model trains in a hobby store.  When his boss and landlord dies suddenly, Finn discovers he has inherited an old train station into which he moves.  His new neighbors are the driver of a food truck, and a preoccupied divorcee who almost accidentally runs him over a couple of times.
Peter Dinklage gives his best performance in this film, ably supported by Patricia Clarkson and Bobby Cannavale.  It's poignant, heart-warming and funny in a bittersweet way.  It wone a BAFTA award and was nominated for several SAG awards and other honors.  In my opinion, Dinklage deserved an Oscar for the role.  This is one of my Top 5 favorite films of all time.
This is a very funny movie. Some might call it a quiet character study. All I know is that I laughed all the way through it.

I didn't care for it. I read all the reviews, I knew it was a Sundance favorite (which, actually, should have served as a warning). I like Dinklage and was looking forward to watching him explore this role. This film was 'built for Sundance' in my opinion. Navel-gazing, shallow, overly contrived and sadly predictable. You never get any closure on the characters, only mis-directed angst. You KNEW there was going to be a self-destructive bar scene. You KNEW there was going to be an overwhelming sense of loss... and as a viewer, I felt the loss was mine. At the end, the overarching expression in the room was ...what the Hell?
No closure... but that's OK, there never seemed a purpose. I enjoyed some of the detail, but lamented so many missing bits. I was distracted from the story line because I lost some continuity. The main character's living arrangement, as presented, left too many questions. What is he doing for water? Is he bathing? Is he eating? How, what? How does he manage to remain shaven and dressed? What is his means of support? Where does he relieve himself? These seem stupid questions but the writer has intentionally contrived the living situation, written in the lack of basic facilities, the lack of water and food and then, after constructing this destitution, makes no effort to show us how the character copes with it. This is completely different form, say, The Terminal, where those questions were answered by the situation. Obviously, the airport has facilities and water, etc. Not here, though, the writer has gone to lengths to construct this isolation and then leaves us to wonder. Why would Joe operate a food truck in THAT location? Because of legacy? the station has clearly ceased to operate as a passenger station. The public no longer passes that way, yet the son continues parking the food truck there because his dad did? The station has CLOSED. Food service trucks DO NOT set up and serve areas where there ARE NO PEOPLE!  This is the vacancy of continuity and logic that Sundance will appreciate in the same way that a blank canvas can be presented as 'art' and certain people will swoon...while the rest of us will just scratch our heads.

There is surely some "brand" name for this type of film but I don't know what it is.  I liked the way the characters were presented and evolved as the story unfolded.  This is one of those "independent film(s)" that are so worth watching.

Should have known Peter would go on to better things...Game of Thrones........wow, what a talent.  And, Patricia Clakson is such a talent and has such a lovely figure, why she isn't in more films I do not know.........this film is played over and over in my home.

Notes on the movie itself - and a SPOILER ALERT. This movie is extremely subtle and riveting. The more times you watch it, the more you'll be surprised.

SPOILER: finally figured out the angry bar scene. The people are NOT making fun of Finn as a dwarf - they're concerned he's socking away too much whisky, too fast. A drinker cheers him as a macho drinker. A couple watches in worry. Even the guys who he had trouble with originally - and are probably feeling ashamed of themselves - note his drinking, and one of them brings him a beer, and pats him on the back. You can almost hear him say, "Slow down on the whisky, man - have a beer."

It's that subtle. One of the great movies. Watchable over and over again.
Peter dinkledge is just brilliant in this. Love him!

If you remember Patricia Clarkson's driving woes in "Learning to Drive," you'll be amused to see her here, early in the movie, twice running Peter Dinklage into the ditch.  This 2003 movie offers some of the same kind of pleasures -- people who are at a loss in their lives beginning, sometimes reluctantly, to move forward into new relationships just at a point where they seem to have taken a self-defeating step backwards.  Dinklage plays Fin (short for Finbar), a dwarf railroad enthusiast from Hoboken who inherits an abandoned station building from a former employer and retreats to it in order to escape being an object of ridicule.  Clarkson is Olivia, the estranged wife of a Princeton academic, who has retreated to a house in the country as she tries to deal with the loss of a child in a freak playground accident.  Bobby Cannavale is Joe, a food-truck operator with a chronically ill father who often requires his attention and who is perhaps sicker than Joe wants to admit.  Both Olivia and Fin are patrons of Joe's truck, and Joe is a pro-active agent in establishing and maintaining relationships, even if his constant chatter and kvetching gets irritating at times, to Fin especially.  The young Michelle Williams (as a librarian) and Raven Goodwin as Cleo, a middle school student who wants to get Fin to talk to her class about trains, both put pressure on Fin particularly to re-engage with world, and as a result (without giving too much away), Fin is able to help Olivia at a critical time.

Tom McCarthy's writing shows a nice ear for the different manners of the main characters, his pacing is economical -- a tidy 90 minutes -- and Oliver Bokelberg's cinematography, both in the indoor locations and in the outdoor locations in which the railway line seems as natural and picturesque as the New Jersey countryside itself, is unshowily effective -- the compositions are unpretentious pleasures for the eye.  The acting is just fine -- this was Peter Dinklage's first major role, and he's very appealing, and Clarkson is a wonderfully natural actress who carries a kind of glamour very quietly.  Cannavale has perhaps the most familiar kind of role, but it's what the emotional dynamic of the movie needs.  Sentimental? Sure.  But the movie is open-ended and doesn't over-promise for its protagonists.  I found it very enjoyable.

A few laughs. And maybe there is a higher symbolic meaning thing going on. But, the characters don't seem quite real enough. In real life; the dwarf would die without one friend, the coffee guy exist nowhere,  i have no idea how he even pays for gas selling a few cups of coffee a day. Let alone himself, his dad with medical problems, and i think a car. He couldn't pick a worst location throwing darts at a map. The woman is somewhat believable but not combined with those two. Maybe the point is these people are broken for different reasons. Maybe im taking living life semi-funtional for granted. Hats off to the filmmakers if they were trying to portray sadness, depression, and frustration to the lot of us. But while there was some resolution in the end, it doesnt feel like it and its hard to see.

The characters are interesting, the acting is ok and the setting is nice.  But the story line?  There isn't much to discuss about that.  It is an illogical short and shallow tale about 3 quirky people with their own set of problems whose lives connect when one of them inherits a deserted train station.  That's it.  Some humor...not much actually.  Almost zero romance.  In the middle of the movie, you may think it is about to take off and become interesting, but it isn't.  I've seen silent movies which communicated their story much better.  It seemed like the writers didn't want the characters to speak much.  As for the ending...I've been trying hard this morning to say something good or pithy or insightful about it.  I can't, however.  It just stops.  It is like 3 kids got tired of playing with each other and went home.

Just a nice film with a nice story. No evil, no really bad elements, a few conflicts, but all in all, the characters are developed so well, each has their own inner conflicts, but three unlikely characters all come together and develop relationships that are charming, complex, yet so simple at the same time. I've had a copy of this movie for years and had never wanted to commit the time. I came across it on Amazon Prime video on my Roku, and I made the commitment. Happy, kind, simple yet complex, Joe is hilarious, Fin is deep and it's so easy to sympathize with him and all he must go through on a daily basis. And the only thing that bothered me is the character played by Patricia Clarkson. She played Olivia and the role was just a bit over-acted. Here she is driving like a maniac multiple times in one scene, running around braless and brainless, no idea where anything is, all flighty, just a bit annoying to be honest. I like her as an actress, but this role was on that ws just not so believable. More so annoying. She's an artist who takes pills, she's weak, has dealt with tragedy, she's supposedly so cool and so laid back , but the blink of an eye she does a 180. I dunno, Finbar and Joe were so well developed, both performances were great and Patricia Clarkson was a great actor. I just really dislike many thing about that particular role. Sorry Patty, it's not you, it's me. But no question, I loved the movie!

Although it's praised very heavily for being so much like real life, and in many ways this is accurate, I found that it was a little unrealistic.  Finn wants to be left alone, and repeatedly rejects the people who want to befriend him.  They are determined to be his friends, though, and they keep on persisting until he finally lets them in.  In real life, though, being strongly introverted usually turns other people away.  Nobody will force a friendship on another person.  That said, it's not a bad idea to be persistent in trying to befriend someone.  This film highlights the fact that people need human connections, and that there's no reason to isolate yourself from others.

WOW! What a gem! This movie is quiet and unassuming, yet very powerful. ALL of the performances (Dinklage, Canavale, Clarkson) are spot on. This always feels like a slice of like where we are the voyeurs, not like a movie where you are acutely aware of the trappings.

It's a simple story about a man named Finn who happens to be a dwarf, and wants to live out his quiet life without getting too close to anyone. Every day people make fun of him or react in ways that are less than polite.
He meets Joe, a loquacious and bubbly guy who for his faults, at least sees Finn as a man (not just a dwarf). Their paths intersect with Olivia (Clarkson) who is a fragile soul herself having lost her son before the movie starts (hence it's not really a spoiler, lol!) and is in rocky condition.

It's a story of how we need each other. "What are we here for, if not to help each other?" ~ G. Elliot
No explosions.  No car chases.  No CGI.  Simply great writing and great movie making.  Dinklage, Clarkson, and Cannavale are at the top of their games.

This movie "chugged" along slowly, but was still interesting. The characters developed at a slow pace also, I wished their stories and backgrounds came more quickly, however, it was still a nice ride. Very enjoyable, however the plot could have been more complicated, but I still liked watching. Like drinking a mellow aged wine, you savor it and enjoy it at a relaxed pace, but are still disappointed when it's finished.
Slow paced character study, three unlikely persons come together as they go about their daily lives.

encourages unsafe behavior on railroad tracks and in railroad rights of way.  Negative implications for children walking on railroad tracks that they might be able to survive being run over by a train.  Most don't and the unsafe behaviors encouraged drop this to a one star rating.

This is really quite a good film. Peter Dinklage, a great actor, gives an excellent performance in the lead role. This is a story about three people struggling through difficulties in their lives and finding support and loyalty and safe friendship with each other. The three main characters, as well as a few supporting characters are interesting enough to hold interest without the film needing constant action or frantic activity. The insights into the struggles of dwarves in this culture was subtle, sympathetic, and excellent. Nothing artificial or stupid here. People drawn true to life. Memorable.

Every time I watch this film I love it a little more. Great ensemble acting. I fell in love with these people and wanted oh so bad to be a part of their small  circle. The shy and damaged Fin. The sad and grieving Olivia. And the effervescent Joe, that one in a million human being whose able to see past the superficial exterior to the beautiful person living within. Oh, if only the world was full of Joes. I feel sorry for the people who couldn't see what a wonderful motion picture this is. It's as if they've failed some sort of litmus test for humanity.

Everyone wants to be happy.

This is a terrific movie, and for all the right reasons. It is first and foremost a minimalist taleone that tells its story with a smallest amount of dialogue, action, setting you name it. Shots take place with hardly a word, and end before they seem to begin. Yet this is not any Ingrid Bergman movie where characters stare at one another with baleful, meaningful looks no, this movie works with an understatement of words, but not of meaningful activity. THE STATION AGENT is Finbar McBride and he is played by the talented Peter Dinklage of GAMES OF THRONE, and though much is made of his being a little person, the part could almost be written for any person with a noteworthy reason for wishing society would leave him alone. Dinklages face is SO expressive, so wounded by the manner in which society manhandles its own curiosity, that his desire to be alone never has to be explained any further and it isnt, not once. No, TSA tells its story in great part due to its bevy of interesting characters. They are each different, each with their own tale that really could have managed a movie of their own. Patricia Clarksons Olivia Harris is a mess of a person, waylaid by a pending divorce caused by the death of her son, who is muddling through life and making a wreck of everything. There is the cute librarian, stuck with a big-mouthed deadbeat boyfriend; there is the elementary schoolchild who sees him first as a human being with a fascinating hobby, and asks him simply, What grade are you in? But the movie really belongs to Bobby Cannavale, a man whose in-your-face charismatic friendliness is so charming and disarming that he could have made Winnie the Poohs Eeyore giggle. He is all heart, and his earnest desire to draw Fin into his life, to simply befriend a man who is so exotically different from anyone he has ever known that it is almost impossible to dislike him. THE STATION AGENT won not only vast praise from critics (and a 95% FRESH rating from Rotten Tomatoes), it has the offbeat charm of, say, Benny and Joon, though decidedly darker in its comic tone. It is a film that really put both Peter Dinklage and Bobby Cannavale on the map, exposure-wise. But more than its awards, it is a movie that is both fascinating and endearing, a movie that will end much too soon, but carry on in your heart and mind.

I saw this when it first came out years ago and totally loved it. I bought it as a Christmas present this past year for my mentally challenged adult son. He is an avid train lover so I knew he would relate to it for that reason and that people who are "different" aren't always treated kindly. He loved it and understood Fin's wanting to hide from the world because of past hurts. He also loved all the scenes that had to do with trains. Thank you so much for my being able to share this treasure with my son and being able to visit with these wonderful people as often as wanted. Lovely and dear movie!!

So much to love about this film, especially the 3 main characters.  Bobby Cannavale (as Joe), Patricia Clarkson (as Olivia) and particularly Peter Dinklage (as Fin) are really exceptional.  And please don't overlook Raven Goodwin (as Cleo) who, with her few scenes, makes quite an impression.

And for a film that becomes a statement on the beauty and importance of friendship, it's so interesting that 2 of the 3 main characters are dragged into it kicking and screaming the whole time.  So cool.

So much great dialogue, but one of my favorite exchanges is this:

Fin: "You promised you wouldn't talk (during lunch), Joe."
Joe: "I haven't said anything for 20 minutes."
Fin: (looks at his watch) "Nine."
Joe: "You timed me?"
Fin: "Mm hmm."
Joe: "That's cold, bro."

I saw this today n' I wanted to like it, but didn't.

Someone from the NY Times mentions that it was 'hilarious'. How? It was honestly not a comedy in the least. Maybe some people are mean and just thought it was funny because of Mr. Dinklage's (Fin's) short-height?

There was one smile from me from one moment Fin said something, but that was it. This movie's just about a lonely man and is quite depressing. People make fun of him and he's become someone who wants to be left alone with his interest in trains. Eventually, he opens-up a little bit. Now, when I read in the writeup that he "...discovers his isolated depot is more like Grand Central Station", that's what I wanted: encounters with a lot of goofy characters and how this person became more interested in people. He really just interacts with four people n' nothing was funny.

And what's up with Fin not even asking Olivia what the heck he did for her to suddenly just be mean to him? It all took place after she spoke to the man she was separated from, and we know what she's upset about later, but she really laid it into Fin before (yelling at him to go away and saying how she's not his mother or girlfriend). I guess he's a shy-guy who's been hurt before, but ... man, say SOMETHING! In the end, we have not details about why he's as he is (using short words...wanting to be alone...not accepting rides, etc.)

Oh, and the three main-folks smoke marijuana. Did something hilarious then? Nope. Fin mentions of how horses are also cool when they are watching a video of chasing a train they made. Wow.

This was just about a beginning of some friendships and there was not much happening. "Pieces Of April", which also stars Patricia Clarkson, is equally pretty-dull and absent of much of a story, but it was more appealing.

So, Peter Dinklage's acting was fine and the lovely Michelle Williams brightened this mess up, but this surely wasn't up to the level of the praise-quotes on the package (a "real treasure" according to Ebert & Roeper; "movie you want to share with others" from NY Times; a "breath of fresh air" according to someone named Leonard Maltin).

A prepossessing but reclusive character, Finbar McBride ( Peter Dinklage), in the frame of a little person, is a magnet for people ; some with good intentions, some with bad. For a long-standing loner, this poses some problems. Fin inherits a train depot in a small town in New Jersey and makes it his home.  Gregarious, affable Joe (Bobby Cannavale), his first acquaintance, runs a little food truck outside Fin's front door.  Olivia ( Patricia Clarkson), his second, presents as more than a little distracted,  repeatedly running him off the road with her car (he walking), as if trying to set a record for the greatest number of pitches of a person into a ditch in the shortest time span. A light and easy humor brightens this story of separateness and connectedness.  Both strangers are insistent on befriending Fin.  In a very small town, likely inhabited by fewer commanding personalities, Fin's barriers pose no obstacle for them. Fin loves trains. He loves to see them, delights in the flickering lights and shadows they cast. His pleasure is to walk their tracks, clock them, watch movies about them and , ultimately,  shoot his own trainchasers. Cleo (Raven Goodwin), an inquisitive and friendly young girl, convinces a very reluctant Fin to share some of his knowledge about trains with her classmates.  He fares well. He shows patience with the curiosity of young children.  By contrast, a bar scene, in which he is alone, reminds us of the cruelty directed at the different one.  Olivia, Fin, and Joe become a cohesive team. Their life stories are eventually shared and, more and more, they become each other's buddies and protectors. The capture, from wonderfully diverse perspectives, of Fin walking the track alone, or as part of a pair, or as one of three in single file is pure choreography. Fin is seen standing atop a rail car, his head framed by the lush green canopy of tall trees  The cinematography is outstanding.  A train passes in full representational glory;  then in another scene it moves by as a reflection on a wall, having the feel and tempo of an early motion picture.  That we are social animals is prominent here, that we suffer wounds that may cause us to isolate is also true,  and the final piece may well be that the longing for that human connection often prevails, as it does in this simple and profound story.  A Sundance winner, this film is brilliantly acted, skillfully written and directed by Thomas McCarthy.  Highly recommend.

This is a movie that delves deeply into the personal lives of three unlikely acquaintances - a fast food van owner, a struggling artist, and a small person with an obsession with trains who unexpectedly moves into town one day.  A friendship between the three of them seems wholly unlikely until they finally decide to do nothing more than spend time with each other, until personal tragedies put their friendship at risk.  The movie is told in a fantastic way, just jumping right into the characters' lives, as opposed to holding the viewers' hands and walking them through the plot step by step.  Certainly a must-watch.

"The Station Agent" is a quirky movie. Three distinct and lonely characters: Fin (Peter Dinklage), Joe (Bobby Cannavale), and Olivia (Patricia Clarkson) form a friendship in a rural town in New Jersey. Fin (Dinklage) inherits an old, deserted train station after his boss dies (Fin works at a tiny toy/hobby train store in Hoboken). Dinklage is an excellent actor, playing Fin perfectly deadpan. Fin is shy and wants to be alone. And being a dwarf doesn't help. Olivia is an artist with her own personal problems. Joe is like a puppy dog: he so wants to be friends with Fin and Olivia. The pacing is slow. The humor subtle. "The Station Agent" is more a character study and a story of interpersonal relationships. Three hapless people find each other. The film is rated R for adult language and some drug content.
Funny, facinating and likeable.

I usually view the phrase "Winner of Sundance Festival" as instructions to "RUN AWAY, VERY FAST!" from bitter experience, but I had heard good things about this film and was not disappointed. Not "change your life" meaningful, just a movie you'll be glad you watched once you've seen it.

I am an avid movie buff, especially the older films from the 40s to 60's -- with a smattering of movies in between those years and present day.

In fact, even though I will watch it online with Amazon Prime....I bought the DVD of it so I can watch it without having to turn the computer on.

Peter Dinklage really does an excellent job showcasing the non-stop problems with life ... with a unique life interest in trains and inheriting an abandoned little train station in the middle of nowhere ... as a dwarf with all of the abuse he has to take from insensitive people on a regular basis.
He just wants to be left alone...and even in a tiny town that can't happen.

People may see this as a slow-moving story, and I think that was done on purpose.

Finally, this is a film that you should get all of your snacks and drinks set up so you can watch it undisturbed.

The scene where Dinklage and Clarkson meet is hysterical and it gets the ball rolling. Bobby Canavale is the happy go lucky food truck owner who drags Dinklage out of his shell and gets him engaged in living a life surrounded by friends. This movie has its darker side and it deals with all the ranges of emotions. It will leave you with a smile and I hope, like me, you will fall in love with this movie and watch it over and over for many years to come!

It is fascinating how much more can be achieved in a movie when the actors slow down. You are drawn into the story, as if you, too,are walking the right of way.  Peter Dinklage (who has New Jersey family connections) is masterful.  The supporting cast is top-notch, led by Patricia Clarkson. Excellent work.  Several story lines (Dinklage the dwarf loner, Clarkson the bereaved mom, Cannavale the fun-loving, but responsible son) merge into one pleasant Summer movie...filmed in that mecca of Summer movies: New Jersey.  Dinklage and Clarkson want to be left alone, Cannavale is the conversational counterpoint, and their solitude is nicely resolved by sharing their lives.

This award-winning film is well worth watching.  The main character is a midget with a lot of pride and dignity.  When he inherits an abandoned train depot, he attracts friends from his neighborhood; all of them are "weird" in their way, reminding us that normal is how much we respect and love one another.  This is a film about hope, especially for anyone who feels marginalized, is weird (like who isn't in some way?)  but okay with living in the moment, and is open to letting others into one's space.  To watch is one thing; to reflect and digest is another.  Do all the above.

My partner and I just watched this movie for the second time.  What great performances by Peter Dinklage, Bobby Cannavale, and the entire cast!  As someone who lived in West Milford/Newfoundland NJ for many years, it is wonderful to see how our old train station was used as a centerpiece for such a unique and wonderful story!  The fact that the film makers also managed to include truly local elements (the hot dog truck and Good To Go Deli down the road in Rockaway, for example) made it all the more special.  I recommend this film to anyone who wants a change from the standard formula films that dominate our cinemas, and to anyone who wants to see some of Peter Dinklage's film work before Game of Thrones.  A quirky, real, human story.  Thank you to everyone involved in creating it!

"The Station Agent" is an offbeat and engaging tale of three rather unique individuals whose lives intersect at an abandoned train depot in rural New Jersey.

Peter Dinklage plays Finbar, who works in a model train store owned by his friend Henry Styles (Paul Benjamin). After Henry suddenly dies, Finbar inherits from him an abandoned train station near the town of Newfoundland, NJ. Finbar decides to move to New Jersey and live at the station where he arouses the curiosity of Joe Oramas (Bobby Cannavale), who runs a roadside coffee wagon and forces himself into Finbar's life with relentless cheerfulness. Finbar also makes the acquaintance of Olivia Harris (Patricia Clarkson), who is going through a divorce and is in mourning for the death of her child.

All three of the principle cast members deliver sincere and natural performances. Peter Dinklage gives a charismatic and restrained portrayal that allows his silence to speak volumes. In contrast, Bobby Cannavale is highly amusing as the chatty and extroverted Joe, while Patricia Clarkson brings out unexpected layers of depth in her performance as Olivia.

"The Station Agent" is sometimes dark and uncomfortable and not a conventional Hollywood feel-good slice of life movie, but it ultimately proves to be an uplifting experience and one that will leave you with a smile on your face.

Peter Dinklage, Patricia Clarkson, and Paul Benjamin are a cast of unlikely characters thrown together in this small New Jersey town. I love that Dinklage has been fortunate enough to get rolls that are truly 3 dementional characters and not only centered around a comedy of his physical differences. His character in this roll is deffinanly shaped by societies reaction to him as a little person...but it's very central to the story as it has made his character somewhat of an introvert and unable to easily form strong bonds with people. Clarkson's character is a bit of a clumsey artist type at first, but we slowly learn she is dealing with a tragic situation in her life which also makes her want to retreat from people. Benjamin plays Joe....a young guy full of life and energy who is so board in this little town he is starved for the company of anyone! Joe who is dealing with an ageing father (which is why I suspect he is still in this small town) basically forces his way into the lives of these two damaged souls, creating this small circle of 3 hesitant friends.

A funny, touching story of an introverted man being brought into a more engaged life. Peter Dinklage, Bobby Cannavale, and Patricia Clarkson form an unlikely trio of friends (into which Dinklage has to be pulled unwillingly). Michelle Williams has a shorter, but charming turn as the town librarian. Full of humor, insight, and enthusiasm for life. I consider it the finest indie of the past decade.

Offbeat and both sad and funny, The Station Agent is a surprise and a wonderful one.  "Fin," a dwarf, is self-possessed and after losing his best and possibly only friend to a sudden death, uninterested in other people whose reactions to him have left him with scars, leaves the city and partially walks to a small town in Newfoundland, N.J.  Here, he moves into an abandoned train station which he has inherited from his former friend.  This arrangement suits him just fine, because trains are what Fin lives for in all their forms such as actual trains, models, books and so on.  The story moves along as "Joe" who runs a food truck, pulls into the property the train station sits on.  Joe is a gregarious type who is clearly fascinated with Fin, but in a disarming way.  Since hardly anyone stops at the food trunk where it sits daily, Joe has oodles of time to kill and attaches himself to Fin who is finally aware that his rebuffs go unheeded and that he may as well give in.  Then, there is Olivia who lives in the town in a gorgeous second home on a lake, an apparent artist, who has left her husband.  She is a careless driver who meets Fin, by literally running him off the road he is walking on (twice!) as he goes to the local convenience store for provisions.  Olivia starts out as quirky but her real life and her memories of her dead child start to take a toll on her. These three, plus a spunky young African-American girl, "Cleo" and "Emily," the librarian make up the bulk of a cast of people who are brought together by Fin's unassuming arrival in town.  It is a tale that explores loneliness and friendship and the realization that life is better with the latter.

Most movies these days tend to be empty of meaning, morals and true depth.  They gloss the surface of important subjects or ignore them all together.  Luckily this movie is different.  The main protagonist, Finn, has issues.  Most of the time he deals with them by ignoring them.  Cloistered in his train station he is willing to live separate from the world, taking long walks on the "right of way" and reading about trains.  Several people make him a part of their lives and help him open up, quieting his demons for a bit and allowing him to see that everyone has their own demons to deal with.  This is a movie about the importance of human interaction and how friends can change our lives for the better.

I love when a movie makes me want to write a review; when it can force a flood of emotions through me all at once. When this happens, I know I've just enjoyed a film. The Station Agent is that kind of film. Released in 2003, the movie Written and Directed by Thomas McCarthy (2012, Meet the Parents, Up) is impressive. I was touched. So many aspects of the story really hit me hard. At only 89 minutes, I admit I was sad to see it end.

The movie stars Peter Dinklage. I have been a long time fan of Dinklage, since long before Game of Thrones. I feel like Dinklage is finally earning the respect deserved as an amazing actor if only thanks to the HBO series. stationagent

The synopsis on IMDB reads: When his only friend dies, a man born with dwarfism moves to rural New Jersey to live a life of solitude, only to meet a chatty hot dog vendor and a woman dealing with her own personal loss. This is more of a simple log line. It does not convey the heartfelt scenes and simple dialogue that builds the story and just moves the plot constantly forward.

Fin McBride, portrayed by Peter Dinklage, is something of a boring man. As a dwarf, he seems accustomed to ogling stares, childish taunts and strangers taking his photograph. While he does his best to ignore the obscene behavior of others, there is no way it does not eat away at him. No way it does not slowly destroy his soul. When his employer dies, he learns he has been left a small piece of property and decides to move into an old train station in an attempt to hide from everyone, from life.

Unfortunately, (or fortunately), his "neighbor," Joe Oramas (Bobby Cannavale), runs an hot dog stand next door. Overly friendly, and chatty, we learn that he lives life to the fullest while dealing with a sick and elderly father.

PeterDinklageThe amazing Patricia Clarkson plays Olivia Harris; a married woman who is dealing with the recent death of a child. Rightfully so, her absent-minded behavior is nearly aloof as she tries to piece together puzzles about life that just won't fit anymore.

It may not seem it, but all three suffer from a need for seclusion, as well as for a chance or opportunity to figure out what life is all about. With no easy answers, with no real definition as to why or how, what or what for . . . the three bond as friends, as foes, as people. Their complex backgrounds are clear and apparent and depressing.

The relationships feel right. Genuine. The minor characters are strong, and just interesting enough to make the entire cast complete, full.

With completely compelling characters and an amazing story line, McCarthy 's has shared with everyone a movie that should NOT be missed. The Station Agent is heartfelt and inspirational. It is one of those rare films that long after it is over, you know will not forget it.  Ever.

Phillip Tomasso,
Author of The Vaccination Trilogy
Very interesting and entertaining movie with wonderful performances (which won many awards - and nominated for many more). Certainly enjoyed this very different movie !

The Station Agent could best be described as a film that offers one a look at the lives of three people struggling to deal with personal challenges. The film was listed as a comedy, but I would not call it a comedy.  My biggest problem with the film lies in how it ties together the lives of the three main characters. This seems to have been staged very artificially. However, the lead character does offer us a different perspective than most "slice of life" type films.
A quiet movie that sneaks up on you.  A great study of unlikely friendships and a masterful display of Peter Dinklage's acting skills.
Great movie. Really enjoyed

A charming movie that brings three unique individuals, Finbar, Joe, and Olivia together in a way that we can appreciate. Not unique in themselves, but in what life has brought them. Each struggles with their situation, and somehow develop a quirky, yet caring relationship with each other. To complicate matters, Finbar and Olivia try to cope with the personal suffering from events and factors that they cannot control.

The film is further enriched with two endearing, supporting characters whose stories we only glimpse in passing. The young schoolgirl Cleo, who like Finbar, loves trains and by her sheer force of will, becomes his friend.  And the local librarian Emily, who first frustrates Finbar and then develops a unique, endearing relationship after revealing her personal problem.

The screenplay is very impressive for such a small, yet appealing story. The characters are not endearing initially, but they grow on you. Each performer was impressive in their own way, especially Peter Dinkage in his role as Finbar.  The cinematography was especially delightful, with the rural scenery and camera angles visually appealing.  And the train chasing scene was fun, though way to short.

Overall, a fine movie. Closer to 4.5 stars than 4 stars.

In an age of mindless entertainment for the masses this film stands out as an example of what can be done without special effects, huge budgets and big names. This is a film for a thinking person and it is one of the best examples of good character development I've ever seen. There are no car chases, gunfights, nudity or explosions; so if you need those things to be entertained, pick something else. If you enjoy a morality play that's deep but not dark, you may want to watch this one.
The main character is very secure in who he is. Even though he is a loner in some sense, he interacts with those around him. At first those interactions are forced upon him but later he seeks out that human interaction from those will become his friends. His strength of character quietly and slowly lifts up those around him. In the process, his life becomes better. He's not the conductor, he's "The Station Agent".
I really enjoyed this movie.

Three characters cross paths in this quirky story about a reclusive man named Fin who inherits a train depot property and sets out to live there, presumably because he has nowhere else to go after the death of his friend and owner of the model train store where they both worked. After he arrives at the depot, he meets two locals who add comedy and drama to this story. The three become friends and the film looks into how the two locals are drawn to the mysterious Fin and his world of trains. The film moves slowly and quietly drawing you into the small-town story of these ordinary but extraordinary people. I found my self laughing during very subtle, oddly humorous scenes that just snuck up on me. The actors do a great job in this peek into the lives of three very different characters. I enjoyed it very much.

I apparently got it mixed up with another movie and thought it was going to be a taut political thriller from Brazil (???) --- totally wrong. Instead, it's a simple story of a man (Peter Dinkelage from "Game Of Thrones") who gets the opportunity to to get away from the world that has taunted him all his life, but instead, finds acceptance that he'd never experienced before.  Also featuring Bobby Cannale ("Boardwalk Empire") and the always wonderful Patricia Clarkson. Don't wait to see it like I did --- watch it today!

I didn't think it was exceptional. Slow moving in parts but that is what best told the story. It show how we are interconnected even though we have little or nothing in common.

Good story. Enjoyable characters. Laid back.
Good ensemble acting. Would like to know more about the characters as their lives go forward.
Slow character study, and you don't really get to know them.  Not much dialogue, not much joy, not many laughs.  Save your time and pick something else.
The story, characters were just fabulous to watch. The story is simple and yet interesting . We really didn't want it over at the end.

The Station Agent is attractive because he has a natural ability to live within Presence -- which makes him attractive in a way that seems disturbing to him, but is most precious to those who meet him.  So easy to surrender to this movie completely, as the players in this movie move into their lives and weave themselves into each other's lives in such a way as to involve the viewer with every fiber of their being.  I will watch this movie again and again; it is that good.

Its a great film!  Totally loved the development of the characters, simple and real.  Each actor was well chosen for the part.  I loved how Fin's friends loved him without any attention to his physical size. No Hollywood action, just good writing and acting.

The ending could have been a little less vague, just from an emotional standpoint just when it gets interesting it fades to black Sopranos style. Why is a good movie, solid acting, and the script keeps moving at a deliberately slow pace so you get to see the actors show emotion.

I saw this movie several years ago and found it interesting. This time around... it is a fabulous story how we see different personalities of the 3 main characters converge and clash. Yet the minor players in the movie keep the movie moving along. This is not a fast paced adventure, more subtle.
I was hoping due to it''s reviews that it would be better.  I watched it longer than I normally would have in hopes that it would get better.  i wouldn't recommend to a friend.
The Station Agent is a character study of three gently flawed people, outsiders in a small country town, learning to accept each others weaknesses.

This movie is about as close to perfect as it gets - great acting, lovely storyline, feels very literary in tone and style, which for me, made it all the better. Good to watch if you're feeling like something funny, real, sad, inspiring, and fully rounded.
I was very disappointed in the movie, especially after reading the description about how funny it would be and that I wouldn't want it to end.  It was very slow moving and depressing.
Although the pace is rather slow the movie successfully draws the viewer in to the lives of these intriguing people.
This ia a funny and suspensful stotry with some love story thrown in just for kicks. It has a nice plot. A nice old depot like this one in many towns today.

We had never heard of the movie and watched the trailor and didn't know what to expect.
It was a really nice movie that was very simple in the subject nature but had a nice meaning to it.
We think you will like it...Id recommend it to a friend...
Makes you think about how friendship is found in unlikely places. I disliked the amount of swearing. I would not recommend it.
good movie. I'll leave it to other reviewers to explain it better, but this deserves to be 5 stars on amazon, so I'm reviewing to bump it up.
The movie is Quirky but good . A little slow but it made me keep watching. Love Dentch and Clarkson .
I was pleasantly surprised at the way the director brought this edgy and captivating movie!  The movie left me feeling uplifted and was thoroughly enjoyable.
Enjoyed the relationship between the three main characters.  Nicely developed.  Also like that it was a free streaming video with amazon prime.  Hard to pass that up!

This was a good insight into life for dwarfs without being sentimental or unrealistic.  The photography was also excellent.  The story stands on it's own even if the main character had not been a dwarf;

Recommended for those who get saturated by explosions, obviously unreal car-chases, beat-em-up slug fests. This one is a beautiful study in how mismatched people can learn to get along and become friends.
The movie plot was realistic and entertaining and the acting was excellent, particularly the male leads. I could watch it again.

A wonderfully made story about loss and friendship with a fun group of quirky characters.  It is methodical and moves slowly, so if you need explosions and non stop action to make it thRough a film, this one is not for you!
Warm, funny, beautiful film. Characters that will stay with you. Excellent cast--- who form a trio with whom you want to hang out
I believe only film nerds could like this movie.  Don't watch it for a bit expecting it to get better.  It never does.
A wonderful story of real people living lives that meet and succeed and actually helping each other without obviously trying.

Started a little slow but as it progressed, I became more and more absorbed in the lives of the characters. The ending was a little abrupt, though. Days later, I still find this movie on my mind. I would recommend it to a friend.

This movie was a real surprise for me.  I had not heard of it before so when I ran across it I thought why not.  My husband and I both were quite thrilled with the whole movie.  I found myself rooting for the characters.  I'd watch it again.
The pinnacle of what indie movies are all about! Excellent! Great cast, music, and feel. Charming, a movie you'll watch again!
This is a quirky but well acted movie with a strong message.  No formulas here, and I really enjoyed each actor doing his/her thing.  Well done.

Our son recommended we watch this so we got it.  While I think the acting was top notch, the story was very slow moving and tedious.  It seemed to have some mystery, but no answers, like how did the little guy make a living to allow him to live in the station, was he successful with either of the women, and why did the coffee wagon park at the end of the road instead of somewhere where people passed by?

It was 10 min. after it ended to figure out what it was really about.  If I tell you it will give away the plot, but here's a hint: ask yourself why everything wants to confide in Vin, when he has (it appears) the personality of a rock.

Great movie-artistic ensemble. This is an unusual plot mostly around a man who is a dwarf-great guy just doesn't like people. Unusual plot-no car chases, excessive language, nudity or zombies! But it does entertain!
Very good dialog and screen play.  Better than average character play.  The dwarf was definitely the star of the show.
There are no explosions, no big mysteries, no dramatic plot twists. And yet, at the end of this movie, I felt rewarded and fulfilled from the unique story line of unusual friendship in a small town.
A slow moving story with a weak plot but makes a very strong point of the need to have friends in your life and tolerance of their shortcomings.
I'm not a critic or anything, but I loved the characters in this film. I loved that it wasn't "Hollywood" where the good guy gets the girl etc. Not trite. Quite enjoyable

This movie is slow, but not boring.  It is an interesting and touching character study come to life.  The lives of three special people converge onto one another.  We get to witness the development of relationships, the beauty and frailty of humanity, and come away with a few life lessons.  Lessons gleaned by watching these masterful actors play out an excellent story.  Not forced morals or ham-handed beliefs shoved onto us.  Instead, you pull meaning into your own life after watching this film.  The way you do after finishing a well-written novel.

Worth watching.  It is a thoughtful piece that entertains you at the pace of a leisurely drive.  Masterful in every way.  Cannot cast better actors than these.

I wish we had more films like this.
Interesting and well acting little story. Nothing much happens, but it offers insights into how some people look at others simply as people and others see only how they are "different".
I liked this very quiet movie but than again I am a huge fan of Peter Dinklage.  It is very angsty though and not alot of happy things happen except for the bonding of friendship.

"Most men lead lives of quiet desperation and go to the grave with the song still in them." Henry David Thoreau.
Perhaps the main character wanted to live that sort of life, but instead due to others, he begins to see his own song.  Peter Dinklage, Patricia Clarkson, and Bobby Cannavale bring to life the story of three people each  living their own lives brought together by chance circumstances. While the main character is, yes, a Dwarf, the story does not center on his disability but his desire for isolation from being hurt as a result of it. Many of us can identify with this desire for all of us have been deeply hurt at one time or another. This is not about love or about some profound life lesson, but a simple story told with complex characters in a way that leaves a lasting impression.
Quirky movie, Pretty good story though. Liked storyline between three main actor. Wished  they had gone a little farther with the station theme.
The film develops very well as the characters interact. Adds a bit of railroad knowledge to your vocabulary. Highly recommended.

Peter Dinklage is so much more dynamic in his acting than this slow moving movie allows.  It is a nice depiction of learning to accept oneself, but just seems to fall short of his strengths.  He is much mightier than his size allowed in this picture.
I could not get into this movie. Too slow and subject matter not interesting in the least. Normally I am a fan of quirky movies but not this one. Sorry thumbs down on this one.
Good movie, Tends to drag at times.....Worth watching for the acting!!!  Great situations... Loved the little Italian stallion food truck.

This is one of my favorite indie films of all time. You would think that the story of a quiet introverted man would drag, but this movie never does. Long before "Game of Thrones," Peter Dinklage was doing brilliant stuff here, and Patricia Clarkson is wonderful as usual. Even if the premise doesn't appeal to you on the surface, give this film your attention. It won't let go.

Some quirky characters who obviously cared for each other. Slow moving with an underlying message to take people as they are. Well acted and all together enjoyable. Welcome relief from the all too typical violent and overly sexual movies of today.

I struggled writing this review (preceding 5 words were written as an afterthought) - This movie was very slow and not a lot happened in it, however, for some reason I liked it.  I think had it not been for the character Joe I wouldn't have liked it but he had this optimistic happy personality whereas Olivia was sad and Finn preferred few words and keeping to himself because of him being a dwarf (his words) and the way people would react to him.  There wasn't much storyline, just the day to day struggles of these three people and their interaction with each other ultimately making their lives happier.

My husband and I were in a movie grazing mood.  Nothing too heavy, but interesting enough to satisfy. We saw this film, shrugged, and hit "play." Both of us found ourselves rather mesmerized by the funky character development.  Sometimes friendships emerge by what we DON'T have in common.

The best kind of movie is the one that explores relationships. You know, without blowing up things or utilizing fantastic technology that won't exist for another ten decades. The kind of relationships that make you think, "Hm. I could totally see myself in that situation. With those people."

Even when the setting is a s***ty little New Jersey town where no one lives. Because the portrayal of the characters is realistic without looking like something you see everyday. If you wanted everyday, all you'd have to do is keep doing what you're doing or go to the Wal-mart, or to church, or to your job. This film puts the characters in an unusual circumstance, bringing three people who otherwise would not have come together as friends, and all because one of them inherited a piece of crap property that, so far, no one cared about or even noticed.

Films like this remind one how simple a story can be told, and how enjoyable something simple is to watch. Definitely recommended for anyone who enjoys watching Peter Dinklage. The cast is small, and the story is lightly engaging, and there's a few laughs along the way too. This is what film is meant to be.
Two enjoyable actors to watch in a very quirky movie. Not quite sure what it all added up to in the end, but it was an enjoyable time spent.

There's a lot I could criticize about this film, however, I'm a "feel" kind of person and this one drew me in.  No car chases with fiery wrecks, no explosions or comic book type heroism.  Story probably gets a B, Acting gets an A+ however. The cast are magic together, even if we don't know how they all came to be.  Already find myself rambling.  If you want to watch a chill movie on a rainy Sunday afternoon, The Station Agent may suit you just fine.

Patricia Clarkson is just great -- funny, vulnerable, sweet.
Joe is friendly in a very touching way, and Fin' is just head
and shoulders above the crowd.  A jewel of a movie.

This movie won't be for everyone. In the first 20 minutes hardly any words are spoken. Many will find it slow because we are used to fast paced, action movies. This is not that type of movie. This is an examination of the characters and how and why they become friends! More like reading a good book!
Stellar cast, great story, great acting.....fabulous band of misfits help each other with life's problems.  Don't want to spoil it....just watch it.
Nice little story, although it was a bit slow at times.  Pretty good lesson about accepting people and not judging by stereotypes.

Originally watched I because I'm a huge Peter Dinklage fan, but parts of the movie were actually shot in my town. It has a wonderful storyline and pretty great acting. Though, some parts of the movie leave questions in the end - which is why I took off one star (I would've only taken off 1/2 but obviously Amazon doesn't allow that).
This was a really sweet and touching movie without being saccharin. Good actors that have now become quite recognizable. Enjoy!
Enjoyed this movie very much.  Very heart warming.  Great writing and acting.  Actors were very well cast in their roles.
The movie could have been good jut just moved to slowly for us to enjoy our time spent watching it

Fans of Game of Thrones will be delighted to see a younger Peter Dinklage in an understated role that's positively captivating. The rest of the cast is marvelous, and this quiet, unassuming movie pulls you in as you get to know the three of them and see them interact in the most delightful ways.

Highly recommended!
Very cute story, but totally anti climactic. Characters are endearing, making it enjoyable to watch, but the story line was flat.
This is a very good film. Started out a little slow, but soon got into it. Not a real fan of "little people films", but this was . the exception. Acting was superb,

Quirky little (so to speak) movie.  I liked the cast they had assembled and they had some chemistry.  It shows that everyone has their own life issues and everyone deals with them in their own way.  It was just long enough to keep me watching.
No plot. No conclusion. A few humorous scenes. I kept waiting for the plot to emerge, but it never did
Its a great movie about friendship.. Some might findvit slow.. But its the right pace according to me.. Peter dinklage is first class..
This movie didn't really have much of a point other than how three people became friends.  Characters were good, but the story line was pretty shallow.
This one of the worst movies ever!  It is sad to know someone would rate this movie above a one.  Don"t waste your time watching it.
This will go down as a classic example of what Indie movies are all about. Good storyline, good acting, good directing, etc.

3 people on a collision course to a life long friendship and one hot Michelle Williams make this lighthearted dramady worth your time. Peter Dinklage' pre lannister days, is moving in a understate performance as a railfan who inherits a small piece of property that comes with some off center people.
First, I live near there and loved seeing the space.  But, the best is the cast and their delivery of the complex lives as they intersect. Moving, authentic, timeless.
When you get tired of watching car crashes, explosions and aliens, try this movie.  Easy going, very poignant and you really get to like each of the characters.

Cliched non-starter of a film. Decent acting, but it went nowhere, just like the station agent.
I found it very disappointing, considering the decent reviews it seemed to receive.

Put together a great ensemble cast with an interesting low-keyed storyline and you get The Station Agent! Whether it's the main characters or any of the fine supporting cast it's easy to see why this was a Sundance festival winner. No big surprise that Peter Dinklage, Bobby Canavale and Patricia Clarkson continue to be well-regarded and in demand to this day.
I would rather watch paint dry on the wall, this movie is slow, slow , slow, boring, boring, puts u to sleep.
I kept waiting for something significant to happen. I am not sure what this movie is all about. Nothing happened.
Very sweet story....a tale of friendships forged among wounded personalities that cannot withstand the constant assault of friendliness by the local food truck operator.
I so appreciated the small hero and the agony caused by cruel people's insensitivity. Because of his hardships he is able to comfort and emphasize with others at the brink of despair.
Great movie, develops slowly, and has a great impact towards the end, great cast, none are replaceable, Peter Dinklage is wonderful....

This movie was satisfying on so many levels.  This is a story of three people who find themselves thrown together by circumstance and end up forming an unlikely but real friendship.  The acting is supurb and the dialogue wonderful.  I highly recommend it.
This segment of the human population is not usually cover in today's movies. I thoroughly enjoyed the movie... well acted, sensitive emotional content, unapologetic... mature.
Great acting..  Loved Bobby Carnavale's character.  He's so talented.  Unlikely situations and slow pacing, but likeable characters and... who knew there was such an underground Train cult!
I thought the movie had the potential of being something really great.  The storyline could have many directions like a serial, but in so many ways it fell too short. They missed the Caboose (boat).

This movie snuck up on me. I picked it at random, had not heard of it before.  I was never sure where it was going or why, until the end, and that kept me hooked. It is skillfully understated. The writing, the acting and the cinematography were superb.  There were painfully human scenes, and joyful ones.  I can see where some might say it doesn't really resolve. But it does, in the best way it could have.  Afterwards, for a time at least, you might find your attention to the world more acute, your heart more tender, your spirit more joyful.
The acting, photography, and story are superb.  So often words were not necessary because facial expressions told the story, but when the actors uttered the words, they did  so with impact.

There is very little quality drama on TV these days, and with summer coming, that desert will widen. Even during the year, the good series have shortened their seasons. We turn more and more to amazon prime, hunting for good drama, comedy, and non-fiction offerings. What a nice surprise when we chose The Station Agent one evening this week. It had won at Sundance, so we decided to try it.

It is a beautiful movie that mixes humor and sadder emotions, quirky people and charming setting. Reminded me a little of Big Fish, though not as "magical." Could not have asked for improvement. Really enjoyed it.
Meh.  Cute story but some of the emotional outbursts were incongruent at times.  The main character could have been better developed.
The story is sweet and the actors are Real! There is some humor to lighten the somewhat dark mood. It lags at times though.

Usually I enjoy Independent films, but this one......watched and watched this really slow  movie and then an anti-climatic end with no resolution in the story....oh well, you win some, you lose some...

Love the pace of this film.  Perfect.  Let's you feel the moments of quietude that surround the characters and influence their desire as strangers to be kind and get to know one another.  There is no one else around and each of them carries a loneliness of their own which brings them to together as well as helps them understand when to persist and breakdown the barriers they erect when they are in fresh pain.

Beautifully written and beautifully composed (from the periods of silence, the settings, and the acting).

This one started out a bit odd but it all came together.
The most unlikely set of characters prove that human kindness
& friendship can be just that... Worth watching. JJ

Three solitary people come together and their problems overlap, Friendship is the inspiring answer... Well done in all aspects of
film production...
We were challenged by the inclusion of the agent by the least likely characters in the movie and the rejection by the most needy group.
I enjoyed this movie.  It quietly revealed the strengths and weaknesses of the characters, through the telling of the story.
interesting, witty, well acted and unique!  i really enjoyed this one. relationship movie at its best.  great date night flick.

Actors unknown to me, title I'd never heard of, but easily the best movie I've watched this year. A delightful and moving story of a man who is "different" and the life he's developed to deal with his "differentness." Pair him with two other misfits and you have a tale that teaches the meaning of compassion and personal growth. Plus good doses of human humor. I loved this movie. Will watch it again (something I reserve for lifelong favorites).

Excellently well acted and well written.  It gives a very real (or I assume a very real) view of being different, in this case of living with the physical condition of dwarfism, and presents a picture of how we are all in pain of some form or another.  Friendship, the simple of act of accepting someone for exactly who he or she is, can heal and sustain us.
This was a very quiet thoughtful movie about friendship. The acting was superb and the locale was beautifully filmed. I really enjoyed it.
This is Worth watching.  The calibre of the actors is very high.  It' is not very fast paced, but touching.

This movie starts a bit slow and 'Indy' looking but don't let that determine your perception of this little gem. A heartfelt story of friends and what makes our relationships special. The great characters may just remind you of some of your flunky but meaningful relationships. I loved it and I am not much of a pushover when it comes to movies.

It's a nice-shot movie, the story is well-developed and the scene is beautiful, logical and not awkward at all. The director is a good director I think. However, the story is kind of boring. I am not quite sure what the story is trying to convey, love? friendship? the miserable life as being a dwarf? It seems like there is not such a single point that the story is trying to emphasize. throughout the entire movie, I can feel loneliness deep in each character's soul. Olivia, a divorced lady living alone; Joe, a talkative guy actively trying to make friend with Fin ( probably Fin is the only one he can talk to); Fin, a reserved guy who is the best friend with loneliness. Unlike some metropolis cities like New York, they are ordinary people living in a small town, I can imagine and understand how peaceful and serene the life would be there, though I would definitely feel lonely as a 20+ girl from a crowded big city in China. If I watched this movie when I was still in China, I would definitely be looking forward to the peaceful and wonderful life there in the movie. However, after I have been in the State for almost a year, I feel loneliness in this movie above all other feelings.
Enjoyed the movie even though it was not quite what I expected.  Movie was more serious than what I expected but still enjoyed it.
It was a good story, a little slow but a perfect Sunday afternoon movie. Actors were good. I enjoyed it.
Simple story beautifully told with a cast of would be stars. If you haven't seen this movie definitely put this on your must see list, it is a rare treat.
Great indi flick with a solid cast.  The movie is about friendship and how it can be built by the most uncommon people in an unusual situation.

Definitely an indie film at its heart, this is a slow-paced movie that takes patience. However the acting is suberb and you get to absorb the friendships that these characters forge throughout the movie.
Interesting story of friendship among the least likely characters. Their relationships demonstrate love and caring which is basic in the make up of every human being, but not always evident.
Good movie.  Little slow at times, and heavy at others.  One of those ponder life movies.  But leaves you with good after taste.  31/2 stars

This reminded me of Trees Lounge. It's got a tremendous cast and a good plot. This is not a movie for people who don't appreciate real movies and need to be entertained every 5 seconds with explosions or sex.
Points out that nobody is perfect but we all have a right to feel good about ourselves and our friends
The movie was very slow getting started, but enjoyed the movie overall.  The best part was watching the characters develop.

I was curious to see Peter Dinklage in other roles and he did not disappoint.  This is an independent film that makes you think about interpersonal relationships, about prejudices and how important it is to know someone before forming an opinion about them.  Released in 2003, it remains fresh and touching.  Worth the time to pause our busy lives and slow down with this easy to watch, warm film.

I would've give this five stars if the ending wasn't so abrupt.  It's a lovely film investigating the lives of the people in this small town, kind of like a "The Heart is a lonely Hunter" kind of film.
Boring Sad, depressing movie.  Never seen such misrable people.  Why not have something happy and fun to watch for entertainment!
This movie shocked me because i did not think it would be funny and real but it was. It truly shouts out friendship and what it really looks like.
Not funny at all!  Quality actors, bad story and sooo boring. Even the town where is filmed is boring. Don't bother watching.
A slow-paced movie sbout escaping ones troubles and making new friends to help get over new challenges that life may bring. Good performances.
I started watching this and remembered I had already seen it. So worth a 2nd viewing. Reminds us of the importance of friendships in our lives. Highly recommend it.
A story of life very interesting characters and very well done. I don't know how the critics rated this film but it has been one of my favorites since I first saw it witch is many times.
Tender, funny, unpredictable, touching, inspiring. Great casting. Great acting. Great script. Looking forward to watching this one again very soon.
This movie was so much fun to watch.  It is about four very different people who form a friendship because they happen to live close to each other and they share an interest in trains.
It is OK, but I expected much more from it. There were some good things, like the friendship between the main people,  but I believe the movie could have done so much more, even for a short movie.

This is a movie made for people who like movies that make them think and make them feel.  It is not the usual mindless entertainment!  The characters feel real and like in real life, everyone has their problms, but they manage to rise above them with the help of friends.  Nothing much happens yet the film contains an entire world and so is interesting.

This one caught me by surprise. I did not know what to expect and had not heard of it.  It was a really good movie. Interesting even though it really didn't have a theme or plot. Just a sting of events in a, kinda quirky, guys life..

first rate acting. peter dinklage (from game of thrones) is perfect. he has quickly become one of my favorite actors. I hope he continues to find parts of this quality. a small but insightful film about the human heart, and the power of friendship. dinklage plays a lonely man who because of his size (he thinks) has few friends. when his one true friend dies , leaving him a small piece of property in NJ, an old abandoned train station, he goes there to claim his property and moves in. he and his friend had worked at a train model store. we see dinklage's character trying to avoid human contact, essentially a loner, and the impact some more outgoing people in his new environment (all with their own problems) have on his life. this is not a Debbie downer melodramatic film. it rings true all the way around, and is an uplifting story about being drawn out of one's shell and finding friendship, and the importance of friendship. wonderfully done, a real treasure.

This movie is pretty quirky but I've seen it at least 4 times. I love the cast and they are really strange characters who become drawn to each other. It's a cute movie but there's an underlying message to it....we all need friends.

I found my self relating to most all of the characters. definitely shows how first impression are misleading and how people are different once you get to know them. Everyone has good qualities and not so good qualities. But thats okay. I laughed in parts and felt really humbled in others. Great light hearted movie embracing imperfections which make us human

This was a charming movie, and I enjoyed it thoroughly; however, I found myself puzzling about various events later because there seemed to be gaps in the narrative that left some fairly important information out.  I wish I had watched with somebody else so that we could have talked about it later.
Good movie!  Enjoyed the perspective of life from a little person's viewpoint, along with the travails of life for him.
The kind of movie that is all dialog and no action.  Requires sitting down and giving it your full attention -- I was trying to listen while cooking.  Will watch it again at some point.
Quirky but engaging. A story that has that real life feel, not sanitized and perfect like most movie. No special effects, no sex, no avalanche of profanity, just a story!

This movie did a great job of portraying people as the multi-layered, complex individuals we all are. It shows the emotions we all have and all deal with differently. While it is, at it's heart, a story of friendships, it is not a story of "the epic friendship." It's a story of real life friendships, very heartwarming yet sometimes bothersome.

Have you ever had a daydream about becoming a hermit?  If so you may find a kindred spirit in the Station Agent's main character, Finbar McBride, played by the talented Peter Dinklage.  Finbar's goal of becoming a recluse is not successful,however, and this may be the main charm of this movie.  Finbar, who just wants to be left alone has to contend with others who intrude upon his self-induced isolation. Enter Joe Oramus,(played by Bobby Cannavale) and Olivia Harris (played by Patricia Clarkson).  This quirky trio seems to share few commonalities.  Joe is the extroverted and devoted son who takes over his dad's hot dog/coffee food truck while his father is ill.  Olivia is a shy artist who is dealing with the death of her young son and the demise of her marriage.  And Finbar is  a train enthusiast who has just lost one of his only friends who has left him an old train depot in the middle of Nowhere New Jersey.  Despite their superficial differences, each character attempts to deal with emotions such as anger, grief, and pain by shutting out the world in their own way. Yet the desire for human connection wins out in the end.  The desire to share both the joys and sorrows in life is what unites these individuals in a strong and loyal friendship.  Their initial tenuous and awkward attempts at connection might make us cringe.  It takes a very patient movie viewer to see the story to the "end" where the characters don't have to work so hard at either actively avoiding or initiating human contact.

I found the vicarious journey towards connectedness to be well worth it.  In fact, I can easily say that The Station Agent is my new favorite movie.

This is a film that you may have missed when it first came out (2003) but maybe you heard about it recently due to Peter Dinklage's rise to fame from his portrayal of  Tyrion Lannister in the HBO series Game of Thrones, which earned him both an  Emmy and a Golden Globe Award for Supporting Actor in 2011.  In fact I was one those people who had never heard of The Station Agent until this year (2014).  I first heard about this film from reading a recent Esquire interview with Peter Dinklage. During the interview Dinklage talks about a random but poignant moment when a clearly distraught woman recognizes him on the street.  She tells him that her boyfriend, who had died that very day, was a huge fan of Dinklage and that The Station Agent had been one of his favorite movies.  The woman took this remarkable chance meeting as some sort of special sign.  Dinklage seemed to think so too and described the event as meaningful.  Intrigued by this interview, I decided that I had to see The Station Agent for myself.

For those who said that The Station Agent was not what they expected, I can understand this sentiment.  You really don't know what kind of movie this is until you are well into it.  And for some, it seems that even ten minutes of viewing the movie was enough to call it quits.  This clearly is not a movie to suit everyone's tastes.  While I generally don't like when reviewers categorize people who like or don't like a particular film, I will say that it probably helps if you are an introvert to easily appreciate The Station Agent.  But by no means is introversion a prerequisite for liking or even loving this very unique gem of a film.  Whether you are an introvert or extrovert, the need to be alone with your anger, grief, or pain, is something most of us can relate to and comprehend.

The criticism that this movie is "boring" or that "nothing happens" seems to be the consensus of those who gave this film one or two stars.  The fact that there are so many negative reviews, essentially saying the same thing, seems to illustrate the dichotomous nature of movie goers.  There are people who are going to "get" this type of film and those who have no patience for it.  Some reviewers who gave 1-2 stars actually apologized saying in effect, "I really wanted to like this movie but I just didn't."  Perhaps expectations get in the way of enjoyment of such a film.

One of the expectations generating disappointment was that some thought this would be a laugh out loud comedy.  Maybe, at best, The Station Agent could be described as a dark comedy.  The humor was there but it was very refined and subtle. Some people wanted more action.  Although a lot happens in this film as far as personal growth and change, no, there is not much action packed drama.  Yet the lack of action was a plus for me.  The slowness of the film forced me to slow down as well.  It was only then that I could appreciate the specialness of waiting for a train or even the beauty of what we consider to be awkward silences.  And too, there were those who called this a depressing film.  I can understand how that description could be derived yet having watched the entire movie, I felt the opposite of depressed.  I felt inspired. There was growth for each of the characters, however slow it seemed to happen. The Station Agent seems to be one of those movies that you either love or hate.

And too I think a lot of people might get caught up in the fact that the main character is a little person.  While this fact is addressed in The Station Agent, and sometimes quite profoundly (the bar scene where he stands on the counter), it is not the central theme of the movie.  Finbar hold's his own, if you will.  The viewer is not guided to self-indulge in pity or in lofty admiration for Finbar but rather, to see him as a regular guy who happens to have dwarfism.

Overall I was entranced by the beauty of this film.  It speaks to anyone who has aspired to become a hermit, but underneath, really wishes for companionship.  Sitting on a porch, taking in the fresh air, and sharing a laugh.  These are the moments that friends cherish.  If you give it a chance, this is the film to remind you.
what a weird movie!  It was awesome.  The characters were well done and engaging.  They were an interesting mix in the movie.  Movie listed as comedy, which is a little off.

Great characters:  They don't fit together at all, but they have each others' backs.  Mr. Dinklage needs to be better recognized for his acting.
Do not miss this lovely little film. All the performances are quite poignant .Peter Dink lage is amazing in this role.

I mainly watched this movie because I enjoy Peter Dinklage in Game of Thrones. He doesn't disappoint in this fine story of a quiet, shy man who just wants to left alone so he can watch and study trains. That's not going to happen due to the people he meets in Newfoundland Pennsylvania; chief among them Joe played by Bobby Cannavale and Olivia played by Patricia Clarkson. They are excellent, especially Cannavale who I think almost steals the movie. However he can't completely steal it because Dinklage displays all of his acting skills in his scenes and he carries the movie. The movie was written and directed by Thomas McCarthy. I recommend it highly.

I'm just sorry it took me so many years to actually watch this film.......superb indie dramedy with great characters and subtle but engaging plot.  For those of you who want action films to tweak your 5-star ratings, don't bother.  This film is so much more:  Thoughtful, and at many times quite funny.  Seems to me to comment on our society's alienation of those who are different, but more importantly, makes it so obvious that those who may be different in some way still are human and share the same desires and cares that most of us share.  To be a friend, to need a friend, and to be seen as important in the eyes of others, and to be seen as a whole person who wants to be respected and needed and have those emotions returned, as well. This is one I will ask my adolescent and teenage kids to watch......  Kudos to the director, the writer, and to the three actors for creating such a great film!

It was more like "That was interesting and had some cute lines, some very sad parts, yet friendship won out in the end. I'm glad I saw it, but my life has not been affected too much."  The acting was fabulous, and I loved Joe's character!  He was special!
I really liked this film and will watch it again.  It was truthful without being brutal.  A thoughtful, heart-felt film with an honest ending.
DARK LIBERAL NONSENSE ABOUT HOW EVERYONE'S LIFE SUCKS! Nothing uplifting at alllllll! DON'T WASTE YOUR LIFE ON THIS SUNDANCE FILM AWARD WINNER!
